description: From Middle English weven (“to weave”), from Old English wefan (“to weave”), from Proto-West Germanic *weban, from Proto-Germanic *webaną, from Proto-Indo-European *webʰ- (“to weave, braid”).

entries.meaning: A type or way of weaving.
examples: That rug has a very tight weave.

entries.meaning: (cosmetics) Human or artificial hair worn to alter one's appearance, either to supplement or to cover the natural hair.
examples: The physician should evaluate for a history of tight ponytails, buns, chignons, braids, twists, weaves, cornrows, dreadlocks, sisterlocks, and hair wefts in addition to the usage of religious hair coverings.

verbs.description: weave (third-person singular simple present weaves, present participle weaving, simple past wove or weaved, past participle woven or weaved or (now colloquial and nonstandard) wove)

entries.meaning: To form something by passing lengths or strands of material over and under one another.
examples: This loom weaves yarn into sweaters.

entries.meaning: To spin a cocoon or a web.
examples: Spiders weave beautiful but deadly webs.

entries.meaning: To unite by close connection or intermixture.
To compose creatively and intricately; to fabricate.
examples: to weave the plot of a story

description: From Middle English weven (“to wander”); probably from Old Norse veifa (“move around, wave”), related to Latin vibrare.

verbs.description: weave (third-person singular simple present weaves, present participle weaving, simple past and past participle weaved)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move by turning and twisting.
examples: The drunk weaved into another bar.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make (a path or way) by winding in and out or from side to side.
examples: The ambulance weaved its way through the heavy traffic.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of an animal) To move the head back and forth in a stereotyped pattern, typically as a symptom of stress.
